Take 1ml sample of the chemical solution from the mother tank to a chimical flask. Then add 10 ml of 25%1$ H2SO4 and 15 ml of water with the solution and stir it for few seconds.TThen the chemical flask with the sample is set under a burette containing 0.1N K2MnO4 next 0.1N K2MnO4 is added to the sample solution one drop at a time until the solution turn into light pink color. The no of 0.1N K2MnO4 drops required in the reading that is used to calculate the amount of H2O2 present in the mixing tank.100%2$ H2O2 gm per 1 liter of solution is present in the mixing tank=3.4%3$ reading.

Take 1ml sample of the chemical solution from the mother thank into a \n chemical flask. Then add 25ml of water with the solution and stir for few seconds.Next add 1-2 drops of reagent onto the sample solution,this will trun the solution into light pink color. Then the chemical flask with the sample is set under a burette containing 0.1N HCl acid next HCl added to the sample solution and drop at a time until the light pink color disappears. The no of 0.1N HCl drops required is the reading that is used to calculate the amount of\n NaOH present in the mixing tank.

## Molarity is the number of moles of a solute dissolved in a 
 liter of solution.
 ## Normality is the number of equivalents of a solute dissolved in a liter of solution.
 ##What is the difference between “the number of moles” & “ the number of equivalents”?
 The number of moles =
 The number of equivalents =
 The equivalent mass =
 For acid, n = Number of H+ ion per mole of acid
 For base, n = Number of OH- ion per mole of base
 For salt, n = Number of positively charged ion per mole of salt
 For reducing agent, n = Number of e- lost per mole of substance
 For oxidizing agent, n = Number of e- gained per mole of substance
 Suppose we have 98g H2SO4 (molar mass: 98 g/mol) in 1L solution.
 Number of moles: = 1 mole
 M= = = 1M (mole/L)
 N=
 Number of equivalent =
 Equivalent mass = = = 49/ equivalent
 Number of equivalent = = 2 equivalent
 N = = 2N (equivalent/ L)
 The same solution, but the concentration is 1 M in terms of molarity, but 2N in terms of Normality.

Weigh a glass stoppered flask, quickly add about 1 ml of sample, 
 stopper immediately, and reweigh.
 Add 50 mls of H20 and titrate with standardized 1.0N NaOH using methyl orange as indicator.
 One ml of 1.0N NaOH = 0.04904 g H2SO4.



ADDITIONAL DETAILS:

Let's say the amount of H2SO4 you have in the flask is 1.15 grams (You get that by weighing the empty flask,
 putting the acid in, and reweighing it. The difference is the amount of acid you added.)

Then you add the 50 mls water and titrate to a methyl orange endpoint. You see that you used 22.1
 mls of the NaOH solution. The NaOH solution was standardized at 1.052N. Here are the calculations:

22.1 mls X 1.052 X 0.04904 = 1.14 grams of H2SO4

Then divide that number by what you started with (1.15 grams):

1.14 divided by 1.15 = 99.1%1$ purity

Reaction: H2SO4 (aq) + 2NaOH (aq) --- > Na2SO4 (aq) + 2H2O (l)

Sulfuric acid Purity %2$=

Sulfuric acid Purity %3$=(Burette Reading X N of NaOHX0.049)/(Sample weight) X 100

Chemicals:
 Caustic soda (NaOH) ...................... 1.0N Solution
 Phenolphthalein (C20H14O4) ........0.1%1$ solution
 Hydrochloric acid (HCl) ................2.0 gm + 100ml Water
 Testing Procedure:
 2.0 gm Hydrochloric acid and 100 ml Water and Phenolphthalein- As Indicator (3 drops) are taken in a glass flask.
 Caustic Soda is kept pouring from burette into the flask drop by drop until the solution color turns into pink.
 Burette reading is taken
 Reaction: NaOH(aq) + HCl(aq) NaCl(aq) + H2O(l)
 Calculation:
 HCl Purity %2$=
 HCl Purity %3$=(Burette Reading X N of NaOH X0.0365)/(Sample weight) X 100

Chemicals:
 Caustic soda (NaOH)............................ 4.0% solution/ 1.0N
 Phenolphthalein (C20H14O4) ...............0.1%1$ solution
 Acetic Acid (CH3COOH) ....................2.0 gm + 100ml Water
 Testing Procedure:
 2.0 gm Acetic acid and 100 ml water and Phenolphthalein- As Indicator (3 drops) are taken in a glass flask.
 Caustic Soda is kept pouring from burette into the flask drop by drop until the solution color turns into pink.
 Burette reading is taken
 Reaction: NaOH + CH3COOH = CH3COONa + H2O
 Calculation:
 Acetic acid Purity %2$=(Burette Reading X N of NaOH X0.06)/(Sample weight) X 100
Acetic acid Purity %3$=

Procedure:-
 take 1-2gm sample of oxalic acid and dissolve in 50 ml water
 Add 2-3 drops Phenolphthalein indicator.
 Fill the burette with 0.1N NaOH solution.
 Titrate the sample against 0.1N NaOH solution up to pink color.
 Note the reading and calculate the strength.



Reaction: (COOH)2 + 2NaOH → (COONa)2 + 2H2O
 1mol (COOH)2 will completely react with 2 mol NaOH to produce 1mol sodium oxalate and 2 mol H2O
 %1$ Purity of Oxalic Acid 
 %2$ Purity of Oxalic Acid =(BR x N of NaOH x0.045x100)/(Sample Weight)

PURITY TESTING PROCEDURE OF CITRIC ACID(C6H8O7)

 Procedure:-
 take 1-2gm sample of Citric acid and dissolve in 50 ml water
 Add 2-3 drops Phenolphthalein indicator.
 Fill the burette with 0.1N NaOH solution.
 Titrate the sample against 0.1N NaOH solution up to pink color.
 Note the reading and calculate the strength.


Sodium Hydroxide + Citric Acid —> Sodium Citrate + Water + Heat
 C6H8O7+3NaOH Na3C6H5O7+3H2O+ Heat
 Molar mass of C6H8O7 = 192.12352 g/mol
 Indicator: Phenopthlein


Citric acid Purity %1$=
 Citric acid Purity %2$=(Burette reading X N of NaOH X 0.064)/(Sample weight) X 100

Boric acid is determined by acid-base titration method i.e
 Direct titration method.

 Boric acid is a weak acid and hence it cannot be determined quantitatively in aqueous solution 
 with standard Sodium hydroxide solution using visual indicator. However it can be determined by
 titrating with standard sodium hydroxide solution in the presence of polyhydric alcohols such as
 glycerol or mannitol because Glyceryl boric acid which is formed on treatment of Boric acid with glycerol.
 This Glyceryl boric acid acts as a strong acid and can be titrated against a standard Sodium hydroxide
 solution using visual indicator (Phenopthlein).
 4 H3BO3 + 2 NaOH = Na2B4O7 + 7 H2O

 Boric acid reacts with sodium hydroxide to produce sodium borate and water.
 Boric acid actually ionizes by accepting a hydroxide ion (and thus an electron pair) from water,
 rather than by donating H+.This makes it a Lewis Acid
 B(OH)3 (aq.) + H2O ---------> B(OH)4- (aq.) + H+ (aq.)
 The tetrahydroxyborate ion, in turn, can yield something that should look familiar.
 4B(OH)4- (aq.) + 2H+ (aq.) --------->B4O72−(aq.)+9H2O


Again, we are dealing with a Lewis Acid, not a classic "proton donor", 
 so these equations don't give us the typical Arrhenius acid-base equilibrium expressions (yet).
 Notice here the tetraborate ion, B4O72− , which occurs also with the ionization of borax. 
 In a borax-boric acid buffer solution (~ pH 9), tetraborate and monohydrogen tetraborate are
 actually the primary species, as long as the boron concentration is greater than about 0.025 M.
 Equations 3 and 4 show us that a connection exists in solution between tetraborate, tetrahydroxyborate,
 and boric acid.
 In theory, it takes four moles of boric acid to yield one mole of B4O72- in solution.
 If we quadruple the coefficients in Equation 1 to correspond with Equation 2, we get 4B(OH)3.
 Equation shows what happens when we combine the two equations:
 4B(OH)3 (aq.) ---------> B4O72−(aq.)+ 5H2O +2H+ (aq.)


Notice that the H+ is now on the right, which is consistent with the fact that boric acid yields
 an acidic solution. Because H2B4O7 is not a strong acid, though, it does not completely ionize.
 First ionization (Equation ):
 H2B4O7 (aq.) --------->HB4O7- (aq.) +H+ (aq.)
 Second ionization (Equation ):
 HB4O7- (aq.)--------->B4O72- (aq.)+ H+ (aq.)


%1$ Purity of Boric Acid =
 %2$ Purity of Boric Acid =(Burette reading X N of NaOH X 0.124)/(Sample weight) X 100

PURITY TESTING PROCEDURE OF LACTIC ACID(C3H6O3) Procedure:- 

 take 1-2gm sample of Lactic acid and dissolve in 50 ml water
 Add 2-3 drops Phenolphthalein indicator.
 Fill the burette with 0.1N NaOH solution.
 Titrate the sample against 0.1N NaOH solution up to pink color.
 Note the reading and calculate the strength.
 Sodium Hydroxide + Lactic acid —> Sodium Lactate + Water
 NaOH + C3H6O3 → NaC3H5O3 + H2O
 Molar mass of C3H6O3 = 90.08 g/mol
 Indicator: Phenopthlein


Lactic acid Purity %1$=

Lactic acid Purity %2$=(Burette reading X N of NaOH X 0.09)/(Sample weight) X 100

PURITY TESTING PROCEDURE OF PHOSPHORIC ACID(H3PO4)


Procedure:-
 take 1-2gm sample of Phosphoric acid and dissolve in 50 ml water
 Add 2-3 drops Phenolphthalein indicator.
 Fill the burette with 0.1N NaOH solution.
 Titrate the sample against 0.1N NaOH solution up to pink color.
 Note the reading and calculate the strength.


The actual reaction will depend on the relative amount of sodium hydroxide. 


Equal volumes of equimolar solutions: 
 H3PO4 + NaOH --> NaH2PO4(aq) + HOH 


As the relative amount of OH- increases, you could get
 H3PO4 + 2NaOH --> Na2HPO4(aq) + 2HOH 


And with a substantial excess of NaOH, then you get 
 H3PO4 + 3NaOH --> Na3PO4(aq) + 3HOH
 Phosphoric acid Purity %=

Phosphoric acid Purity %1$=(Burette reading X N of NaOH X 0.03267)/(Sample weight) X 100

PURITY TESTING PROCEDURE OF HYDROGEN PEROXIDE (H2O2) 


Chemicals: 
 Hydrogen Peroxide (H2O2) ...................... 2.0 gm
 Sulphuric Acid (H2SO4) ...........................20%1$ solution 10ml
 Potassium Permanganate (KMnO4) ..........0.1N Solution

 Testing Procedure: 
 Hydrogen Peroxide (2.0 gm) and Sulphuric acid (10ml or 2gm) are taken in a glass flask.
 Potassium Permanganate is kept pouring from burette into the flask drop by drop until the 
 solution color turns into pink.
 Burette reading is taken 
 Reaction: 2MnO4-+ 6H++ 5H2O2 5O2+ 8H2O + 2Mn2+
 Calculation: 
 H2O2 Purity %2$= =
 H2O2Purity %=(BR X N of KMnO4X0.017)/(Sample weight) X 100 = (BR X M of KMnO4X0.085)/(Sample weight) X 100

PURITY TESTING PROCEDURE OF SODIUM HYDROXIDE (NaOH)

 Procedure:-
 Take 1-2gm sample in a titration flask and dilute upto 50ml
 Add 2-3 drops of 1%1$ phenolphthalein indicator
 Fill the burette with 1.0N HCl solution.
 Titrate the said solution against 1.0N HCl solution untill color disappear.
 Note the reading and calculate the strength.
 Reaction: HCl + NaOH ==> NaCl + H2O


Calculation:-%2$ Purity of Caustic 

%3$ Purity of Caustic =(BR x N of HClx0.04x100)/(Sample Weight)

PURITY TESTING PROCEDURE OF SODIUM BICARBONATE (NaHCO3)

 Procedure:-
 Take 1-2gm sample and dissolve in 50ml water
 Add 4-5 drops of 1%1$Methyl orange indicator
 Fill the burette with 1N HCl solution
 Titrate the sample against 1N HCl until the color become red
 Note the reading and calculate the strength


Reaction: NaHCO3 + HCl → NaCl + CO2 + H2O
 %2$ Purity of Sodium bicarbonate 
 %3% Purity of Sodium bicarbonate=(BR x N of HCl x0.084x100)/(Sample Weight)

PURITY TESTING PROCEDURE OF SODA ASH (Na2CO3)


Procedure:-
 Take 1.0 -2.0 gm sample in flask and dissolve in 100 ml water
 Add few drops of 1% Methyl orange indicator
 Fill the burette with 1N HCl solution
 Titrate the sample against 1N HCl solutions until the color become red
 Note the reading and calculate the strength


Reaction: Na2CO3 + 2HCl ==> 2NaCl + H2O + CO2
 %1$ Purity of Soda ash 
 %2$ Purity of Soda ash=(BR x N of HCl x0.053x100)/(Sample Weight)

PURITY TESTING PROCEDURE OF SODIUM SULFATE(Na2SO4)

 Na2SO4･nH2O (n=10 or 0)
 Mol. Wt. decahydrate 322.20
 anhydrous 142.04


Definition: Sodium Sulfate occurs as two forms: the crystal form (decahydrate) called Sodium Sulfate
 (crystal) and the anhydrous form called Sodium Sulfate (anhydrous). 


Content: Sodium Sulfate, when dried, contains not less than 99.0% of sodium sulfate (Na2SO4). 


Description: Sodium Sulfate (crystal) occurs ascolorless crystals or as a white crystalline powder.
 Sodium Sulfate (anhydrous) occurs as a white powder. 


Identification: Sodium Sulfate responds to all tests for Sodium Salt and for Sulfate as described
 in the Qualitative Tests. 
 Purity: Dry Sodium Sulfate (crystal) before performing the test. 
 (1)Clarity and color of solution: Colorless, almost clear (1.0 g, water 10 ml.) 
 (2)Chloride: Not more than 0.11% as Cl (0.10 g, Control solution 0.01 mol/l hydrochloric acid 0.30 ml). 
 (3) Heavy metals: Not more than 10μg/g as Pb (2.0 g, Method 1, Control solution Lead Standard Solution 2.0 ml). 
 (4)Arsenic: Not more than 4.0 μg/g as As2O3(0.50 g, Method 1, Apparatus B). 


Loss on Drying
 Crystal: 51.0－57.0%1$ (105°C, 4 hours).
 Anhydrous: Not more than 5.0%2$ (105°C, 4 hours). 


Assay:
 Weigh accurately about 0.4 g of SodiumSulfate, previously dried, dissolve in 200 ml of water,
 add 1 ml of hydrochloric acid, boil, and add gradually 30 ml of barium chloride solution (1 →6).
 Heat this solution in a water bath for 1 hour, cool, and filter through a filter paper
 for quantitative analysis (5C). Wash the residue on the filter paper with warm water until
 the washings do not give positive tests for Chloride. Dry the residue with the filter paper,
 ignite to constant weight, and weigh accurately as Barium Sulfate (BaSO4). 

 Reaction: BaCl2(aq) + Na2SO4(aq)---> BaSO4 (s) +2 NaCl(aq) 
 Ba2+(aq)+2Cl-(aq)+2Na+(aq)+SO42-(aq) ---> 2Na+(aq)+2Cl-(aq)+BaSO4(s) 


Content of sodium sulfate (Na2SO4) =
 Content of sodium sulfate (Na2SO4) =(weight (g)of BaSO4 X 0.6086)/(Weight (g)of the sample) X 100

PURITY TESTING PROCEDURE OF SODIUM THIOSULPHATE(Na2S2O3)

 Procedure:-
 take 1-2gm sample of SodiumThiosulphate and dissolve in 50 ml water
 Add 2-3 drops Starch indicator.
 Fill the burette with 0.1N Iodine solution.
 Titrate the sample against 0.1N Iodine solution up to Blue color appear.
 Note the reading and calculate the strength.


I2+ 2Na2S2O3→2NaI + Na2S4O6
 Indicator: Starch
 Purity %1$ of Na2S2O3= 
 Purity %2$ of Na2S2O3=(BR X N of I X 0.158)/(Sample weight) X 100 = (BR X M of I X 0.316)/(Sample weight) X 100

PURITY TESTING PROCEDURE OF SODIUM SILICATE(Na2SiO3)

 Procedure:-
 take 1-2gm sample of Sodiumsilicate and dissolve in 50 ml water
 Add 2-3 drops Methyle orange indicator.
 Fill the burette with 1N HCl solution.
 Titrate the sample against 1N HCl solution up to pink color.
 Note the reading and calculate the strength.


Na2SiO3(aq) + 2HCl(aq) ===> SiO2(s) + 2NaCl(aq) + H2O
 Indicator: Phenolphthalein 
 Purity %1$ of Na2SiO3= 
 Purity %2$ of Na2SiO3=(Burette reading X N of HCl X 0.061)/(Sample weight) X 100

PURITY TESTING PROCEDURE OF SODIUM DITHIONITE(Na2S2O4)


The sodium dithionite content can most readily be determined iodometrically. 
 It is dissolved in a neutral formaldehyde solution in a standard flask.
 The dithionite, which is sensitive to oxidation, 
 reacts immediately on dissolving to give the more stable sodium hydroxymethanesulfinate, 
 which can be titrated. 

 Na2S2O4 + 2 CH2O + H2O -> HOCH2SO2Na + HOCH2SO3Na 
 HOCH2SO2Na + 2 I2 + 2 H2O -> NaHSO4 + 4 HI + CH2O 
 However, this method of analysis does not differentiate between dithionite and any 
 thiosulfate which may be present. Since no acid is formed in the iodometric oxidation
 of thiosulfate, but is formed in the dithionite titration, the proportion of dithionite 
 can be determined by subsequent titration of the solution with alkali.

 Assay:
 Add 10 ml of water to 10 ml of formalin, and neutralize with sodium hydroxide solution (1 →25). To this solution,
 add about 2 g of Sodium Hydrosulfite, accurately weighed, and dissolve in water to make exactly 500 ml.
 Measure exactly 25 ml of this solution, adjust the pH to 1.1－1.5 with diluted hydrochloric acid (1 →10),
 and titrate with
 0.05 mol/l iodine for sodium hydrosulfite (indicator: starch TS). 

 1 ml of 0.05 mol/l iodine = 4.353mg of Na2S2O4


Sodium dithionite Purity %1$= = 

 Sodium dithionitePurity %2$= (BR x N of I X 0.0435)/(Sample weight) x 100 = (BR x M of I X 0.0870)/(Sample weight) x 100
strongly alkaline medium: 
 3 Na2S2O4+ 6 NaOH →5 Na2SO3+ Na2S + H2O 


Sodium dithionite Purity %3$= 
 Sodium dithionitePurity %4$= (BR x N of NaOH X 0.0871)/(Sample weight) x 100

PURITY TESTING PROCEDURE OF SODIUM CHLORIDE(NaCl) 

 Procedure:-
 Take 1-2gm sample and dissolve in 50ml water
 Add 4-5 drops of 10%1$ Potassium Chromate indicator
 Fill the burette with 0.028N Silver nitrate solution
 Titrate the sample against 0.028N Silver nitrate until the color change yellow to Brick red
 Note the reading and calculate the strength


Titrate with Silver Nitrate (AgNO3)
 Indicator: Potassium Chromate (K2CrO4)
 Color change: yellow to brick red
 Reaction: NaCl(aq)+AgNO3(aq)= NaNo3(aq)+AgCl(s)
 Purity %2$ Of NaCl= 
 Purity %3$ Of NaCl= (B.R X N Of AgNO_(3 ) X 0.05844)/(Sample Weight) X 100

HARDNESS OF WATER BY EDTA TITRATION

 Introduction
 The ions involved in water hardness, i.e. Ca2+(aq) and Mg2+(aq), can be determined by titration with a chelating agent,
 ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), 
 usually in the form of disodium salt (H2Y2-). The titration reaction is:

 Ca2+(aq) + H2Y2-(aq) ⎯⎯→ CaY2-(aq) + 2H+(aq)
 Eriochrome Black T is commonly used as indicator for the above titration. 
 At pH10, Ca2+(aq) ion first complexes with the indicator as CaIn+(aq) which is wine red. 
 As the stronger ligand EDTA is added, the CaIn+(aq) complex is replaced by the CaY2-(aq) complex 
 which is blue. The end point of titration is indicated by a sharp colour change from wine red to blue.

 Titration using Eriochrome Black T as indicator determines total hardness due
 to Ca2+(aq) and Mg2+(aq) ions. Hardness due to Ca2+(aq) ion is determined by a separate
 titration at a higher pH, by adding NaOH solution to precipitate Mg(OH)2(s),
 using hydroxynaphthol blue as indicator.
 Materials and Apparatus
 50%1$ w/v NaOH solution (50 g in 100 cm3 solution)
 Eriochrome Black T indicator
 pH 10 NH3-NH4Cl buffer,
 Hydroxynaphthol blue indicator,
 0.01 M EDTA (disodium salt)
 water apparatus required for titration,
 Measuring cylinder.

 Procedures
 Part A: Determination of total hardness
 1. Pipette 50 cm3 mineral water into a conical flask.
 2. Add 2 cm3 buffer solution followed by 3 drops of Eriochrome Black T indicator solution.
 3. Titrate with 0.01 M EDTA until the solution turns from wine red to sky blue with no hint of red (save the solution for colour comparison).\m 4. Repeat the titration to obtain two concordant results.


Hardness= X X 

Part B: Determination of concentration of Ca2+(aq) ions
 1. Pipette 50 cm3 of mineral water into a conical flask.
 2. Add 30 drops of 50%2$ w/v NaOH solution, swirl the solution and wait for a couple of minutes to completely precipitate the magnesium ions as Mg(OH)2(s).
 3. Add a pinch of hydroxynaphthol blue (exact amount to be decided by the
 intensity of the resulting coloured solution) and titrate with 0.01 M EDTA until it
 changes to sky blue (save the solution for colour comparison).
 4. Repeat the titration to obtain two concordant results.


Hardness= X X 

a. Total hardness as CaCO3, obtained using the EDTA titration 
 b. Mg hardness as CaCO3 = total hardness – calcium hardness 
 c. Mg2+ = (magnesium hardness as CaCO3) x (24 g Mg2+ / 100 g CaCO3).


Buffer solution preparation:
 measure 50ml distilled water Procedures
 Part A: Determination of total hardness
 1. Pipette 50 cm3 mineral water into a conical flask.
 2. Add 2 cm3 buffer solution followed by 3 drops of Eriochrome Black T indicator
 solution.
 3. Titrate with 0.01 M EDTA until the solution turns from wine red to sky blue with no hint of red (save the solution for colour comparison).
 4. Repeat the titration to obtain two concordant results.


Hardness= X X 

Part B: Determination of concentration of Ca2+(aq) ions
 1. Pipette 50 cm3 of mineral water into a conical flask.
 2. Add 30 drops of 50% w/v NaOH solution, swirl the solution and wait for a
 couple of minutes to completely precipitate the magnesium ions as Mg(OH)2(s).
 3. Add a pinch of hydroxynaphthol blue (exact amount to be decided by the
 intensity of the resulting coloured solution) and titrate with 0.01 M EDTA until it
 changes to sky blue (save the solution for colour comparison).
 4. Repeat the titration to obtain two concordant results.


Hardness= X X 

a. Total hardness as CaCO3, obtained using the EDTA titration 
 b. Mg hardness as CaCO3 = total hardness – calcium hardness 
 c. Mg2+ = (magnesium hardness as CaCO3) x (24 g Mg2+ / 100 g CaCO3).


Buffer solution preparation:
 measure 50ml distilled water &b transfer it in a beaker
 Weight 1.179 mg EDTA & transfer the contents to the beaker having 50ml of distilled water and dissolved thoroughly.
 Weight 16.9 g of ammonium chloride & add it to the content of the beaker. Dissolved thoroughly.
 Weight 780 mg of Magnesium sulphate and transfer it in to the beaker.
 Measure 143 ml of ammonium hydroxide solution and add it to the contents in the beaker.
 Make the volume up to 250 ml mark by adding distilled water. 
 **This solution is used to maintain the PH of water sample between 9 & 10.**
 &b transfer it in a beaker
 Weight 1.179 mg EDTA & transfer the contents to the beaker having 50ml of distilled water and dissolved thoroughly.
 Weight 16.9 g of ammonium chloride & add it to the content of the beaker. Dissolved thoroughly.
 Weight 780 mg of Magnesium sulphate and transfer it in to the beaker.
 Measure 143 ml of ammonium hydroxide solution and add it to the contents in the beaker.
 Make the volume up to 250 ml mark by adding distilled water. 
 **This solution is used to maintain the PH of water sample between 9 & 10.**

Formaldehyde conten test Flow Chart of Formaldehyde Test : Take 1 gm fabric and make 10 to 12 piece of that fabric.
 ↓
 100 ml distilled water take in conical flux
 ↓
 Temp 40 0 C, Time 1 hr
 ↓
 Water bath
 ↓
 After 5 min……20to 30s
 ↓
 Shaking
 ↓
 Cold down at room temp at 30 min
 ↓
 Filtering by filter paper
 ↓
 Only 5ml solution is taken in test tube and also take 5ml nushreagent in that test tube
 ↓
 Another test tube take 5ml distil water and 5ml nushreagent
 ↓
 Two test tube take in water bath 40 0 C at 30 min
 ↓
 Cold down at 30min at room temp
 ↓
 m/c open
 ↓
 liquid take in spectroscopy cell
 ↓
 Note: std range 50ppm


Nashreagent preparation:
 Ammonium acetate :150 gm
 Acetic acid :3 ml
 Acitile aceton :2ml
 Take of 1 liter volumetric flux and rest of distilled water.
 Note : total solution 1L
 All time take in dark place . Prepare those solution to use after 12hr.


Formaldehyde conten test by Chromotropic acid


Each cloth sample cut into 1 square cm piece and boil in 5 ml of distilled water in a test tube (1st test tube).
 A few crystals of chromotropic acid add to 2 ml of 72%1$ concentrated sulfuric acid in another test tube (2nd test tube).
 The cooled supernatant of the 1st test tube add to the 2nd test tube and the mixture heat over a flame.
 A red purple to violet color indicated a positive test (i.e. the presence of formaldehyde in textiles), 
 while its absence indicated that the cloth sample did not contain formaldehyde.
 The intensity of red purple to violet color graded as 1+, 2+, or 3+.
 Clothes which showed the presence of formaldehyde reassess after washing. 
 The textile samples rinse with detergent and water for 5 minutes and then wash with soap.
 After drying reassess for formaldehyde. The intensity of red purple to violet color was note after each wash. 
 A decrease in the intensity of red purple to violet color indicated a decrease in the formaldehyde content after washing.


Chromotropic acid
 Chromotropic acid has the formula is (HO)2C10H4(SO3H)2
 IUPAC Name: (1,8-dihydroxynaphthalene-3,6-disulfonic acid)
 It can be used for as a reagent in the quantitative determination of the systemic herbicide,
 2,4-Dichlorophenoxyacetic acid.
 Chromotropic acid is also used for testing of presence of formaldehyde.
 The usefulness of this reagent in quantitative determination is the formation of a red colouration (peaking at 580nm wavelength)
 when chromotropic acid in 75%2$ sulfuric acid reacts with formaldehyde. The colouration is specific to this aldehyde and
 is not produced from other organic species such as ketones and carboxylic acids.

ETP WATER TEST TOTAL ALKALINITY TEST

 Required chemicals: 
 Phenolphthalein Indicator, Methyl orange indicator, 0.02N of Sulfuric acid. 
 Test procedure:
 Take 25 ml of SAMPLE in to clean conical flask. If Sample PH > 8.0 Phenolphthalein alkalinity is present.
 Add 3 or 4 drops of phenolphthalein indicator. If pink color appears phenolphthalein alkalinity present.
 Titrate with 0.02N of SULPURIC ACID solution up to pink color changes. Note Burette reading. 
 END POINT: Pink color disappears.
 Calculation:
 Phenolphthalein Alkalinity (PPM) = B.R*50*0.02*1000/ Vol. of sample taken.
 Again added 3 or 4 drops of methyl orange indicator.
 Again Titrate with 0.02 N of sulfuric acid.
 End point is: pale orange appears(or violet)
 Calculation:
 TOTAL ALKALINITY (PPM) = Total Burette reading *0.02* 50*1000/ vol. of sample taken.
 Methyl orange alkalinity (PPM)= Total Alkalinity – Phenolphthalein Orange Alkalinity
 0.02 N of sulphuric acid solution preparation: 
 27.8 ML OF CONC sulphuric acid(98%1$) and dissolved 972.2ml of distilled water .
 The above solution is 1 N of SULPURIC ACID solution.
 0.02 N of sulfuric acid solution: Take 20 ML of 1N of sulphuric acid solution and add 980 ml of distilled water.

Cold Pad Batch Dyeing is one of the widely used semi-continuous dyeing process. It is mainly used in the dyeing of cellulosic fiber like cotton or viscose (knit and woven fabric) with reactive dyes. Now a days this process Widely used in our Woven dyeing industry and it is a development process for Knit dyeing industry in Bangladesh. It is primarily a cold method where the dyeing temperature is 20-25°C and use Cold to Medium Brand Reactive Dyes, and so it is called Cold Pad Batch (CPB) Dyeing. A cooling system is used for cooling the Dye liquid and bath also. Cold Pad batch dyeing is a process that offers some unique advantages.

1. Maximum color yield as compared to other methods.
 2. Less requiremernt of Energy, Water and Chemical since fixation is carried out at room temperature.
 3. Cost effective Dyeing Method.
 4. Good levelness of dyeing.
 5. Longer yardages possible to dye.
 6. Elimination of salt during dyeing. (100%1$ Salt Free Dyeing)
 7. Less impact on environmental pollution.

(source: from BENINGER web, Benninger KÜSTERS Dyepad) 100% Salt Free. 
 *Water (-75%1$) (low bath ratio)
 * Energy (-77%2$).
 * Carbon footprint (-78%3$).
 * Cost (-32%4$).

Every process has some drawbacks and it has also: 
 *Sometime listing problem found.
 *Sometime tailing problem found.
 *Unevenness due to uneven
 pretreatment

1. 100%1$ Cotton.
 2. Cotton + Spandex.
 3. Cotton Viscose Blend.
 4. 100%2$ Viscose.
 5. Linen.
 6. Linen Cotton Blend.
 7. Linen Viscose Blend.
 8. Tensile.

*Machine Speed = 40-50 m/min
 *Padder Pressure (N/mm or Bar) L- M-R= 20-30-20 or 1.2-1.5-1.2
 *Dye Bath Level= 25 Ltr or 50 Ltr
 *Immersion time= 1.5 sec
 *Machine Utility= 5.5 KW
 *Pick Up %3$= for Cotton 55-70%1$ & for Viscose 85-95%2$ or more, varies depend on Fabric GSM.

Here color and chemical (alkali) are prepared separately into separate tank which prevent hydrolysis of dyes molecule. At the time of padding both color and chemical liquid are mixed at dye bath (Temp around 20-25°C). Mixing ratio is Color: Chemical =4:1. This mixing process is done by a dossing pump

*Leva Amber CAN = 9.00 g/l
 *Leva Fast Red CA = 0.6 g/l
 *Leva Blue CA = 15.20 g/ln\ *Dekol 1097 = 2 g/l
 *Leonil EHC = 2 g/l
 *Urea =40 g/l

Soda Ash (Na2C03 )== 20 g/1
 Caustic Soda- (NaOH)=3 or 6 g/l


(7.5ml/l or 15ml1 for 36°Be) dyeing. If we need 100 Ltr Liquid for Dyeing, follow the Color and Chemical ratio 4 :1 to make Color and Chemical separately, and so we make 80 Ltr of Color and 20 Ltr of Chemical for dyeing.

 Here Dekol-1097 acts as a Leveling & Sequestering Agent and Leonil EHC acts as a Wetting agent, and Urea used to keep the Dye bath cool and it acts as a Hygroscopic Agent. Here (Soda Ash & Caustic) - Chemical (Alkali) is used as a Fixing agent and also control the pH of Dye Bath.

Batcher/Plate (fabric feed)
 ↓
 J-Box (not Necessary)
 ↓
 Cooling Drums
 ↓
 Application Dyeing in Dye Bath
 ↓
 Squeeze by Padder
 ↓
 Collecting Fabric in Batcher
 ↓
 Rotation (for Color Fixation)
 ↓
 Washing
 ↓
 Shade Check
 ↓
 Transfer to Finishing
 
 1. Firstly the RFD (Ready for Dyeing) Fabric is introduced with Cooling Drum, it is a cooling system here the fabric is cooled down.

 2. Then the RFD Fabric is introduced with pre-mixed dye liquor at Dye Bath. Here Dye Bath Termp arownd 20-25°C and so it is called Cold Pad Batch (CPB) Dyeing. A cooling system is used for cooling the Dye liquid and bath also.

 3. Then it is passed through Padder. The padder effectively forces the dyestuff into the fabric. In the stage excess dye solution is also removed.

 4. After removal of excess dye stuff the fabric is collected in Batcher. The batches are generally enclosed by plastic films. This prevents absorption of carbon dioxide and water evaporation.

 5. After removing batcher from dyeing machine, it is placed at Rotation Point. It takes around 8- 14 hours (Time depends on Shade). Finally as the reaction is complete the fabrics are washed.

*Manufacture: Monfongs Thermex/ Monforts Monotex
 *Production Speed: 40-60 m/min
 *Padder: Kuster Dye Pad
 *Chambers: 3 or S (depend on Manufacturer)
 *Trough Capacity: 25-30 liters
 *Padder Pressure (N/mm): 20-30-20
 *VTG/Airing Zone: 20m of fabric
 *IR Temperature: Range 650°C-850°C
 *Liquor Change: After 3-4min

• It stores the fabric.\n • It is J-shaped metal holder for fabric.\n

• These rollers are steel rollers used to guide the fabric and to provide tension which prevents the crease formation.\n • Guider is rubber coated roller is placed at edge of fabric to prevent and control the width of fabric.\n
These are used to provide tension to the fabric. If the fabric loosens from any roller during the process, this moves up and down to maintain the tension.

*The padder is mechanical mean of applying dye on fabric.

 The padding operation consist of two parts:
 *First immersion of the fabric in dye-liquor in a trough and
 *Second passing the fabric between the two padder to force the dye- liquor into the fabric and also to squeeze excess amount liquor back to the trough.

 Padder is the most sensitive Components dyeing system as any fault developed at the padding stage will not be corrected later.

• Nip rolls must be clean.
 • The hardness for woven is 70-80 degree shore and 50-60 shore for knitted fabric.
 • The padder roll has a steel mandrel that is covered with hard rubber.
 • Both the rollers should have exactly the same hardness otherwise there will be color difference in the face and back side of the fabric.

The pickup%5$ for the different fabric are
 • Cotton = 55-70%1$
 • P/C (50:50) = 45-50%2$
 • Viscose = 85-95%3$
 • Linen= 55-70%4$

• The trough is placed below and in front of the padder.

 • It is U-shaped box with one or more free-running guide rollers of about 10cm diameter each.

 • The volume in the pad trough should be relatively small 20-50 liters Resulting in shade difference caused by variations in immersion time and pick up.

 • The pad liquor trnover time should be as fast as possible less than Sminutes.

 • Immersion time: Should be 1-2s

• Airing zone is used because sometimes the light GSM fabric has face and back variation so we used airing zone.

 • The airing zone is placed between the padding and drying for better swelling and penetration of the dye

 . These rollers are Teflon coated to avoid stains on the fabric due to rusting and stickiness of chemical.

• The intermediate drying phase. Temperature Range 650°C-850° C.

 • To get even and uniform results especially for medium and deep shades.

 • Dye molecule tend to diffuse with water molecule as they migrate from the wetter towards the drier part if the fabric.

 • Migration stops when only bonded water molecules and moisture content of the fabric dropped below 30%

• Gas or electrically heated.

 • The emitted IR wavelength should correspond maximum absorption value of water (3µm).

 • Equilibrium setting uptime.

 • Air passage before pre-drying (dye penetration).

 • Cleaning of guide rollers

In the thermo fxation (also incorrectly called thermosol) process of dyeing, The cotton fabric dyeing temperature range 100°C-160°C which is depend on the process of dyeing. For synthetic fabric the disperse dyes diffuse into the polyester fibers on bringing the dye-padded fabrics to temperature of 200-280°C for a contact time of 60-30 seconds because the polyester has the compact structure and having 85% of crystalline area so at high temperature the pores of the fiber are open which allows to enter the dye in the highly crystalline area.\n\n

• There are three or five drying chambers (depend on manufacturer).

 • There is water blower which sucks air from the atmosphere and circulates that air by centrifugal action in whole chamber.

 • There is a gauge on each dryer which is showing the balance of air inside the chamber.
• There are total two curing chamber i.e. used when dyeing with polyester or with disperse otherwise as a drying chamber.

• These are provided at the inlet and outlet side of the thermosol machine.

 • These are hollow steel drums and used to maintain the temperature of the whole lot water filled inside the drum to cool it.
